definitions.definition: something that a particular person or organization is responsible for

definitions.definition: important matters that need to be dealt with or discussed

definitions.definition: a matter, an event or a situation

examples.text: That plane crash was a terrible business.

definitions.definition: the fact of a person or people buying goods or services at a shop or business
definitions.labels: (especially North American English)also British English, formal

examples.text: We're grateful for your business.

definitions.definition: the things that are discussed at the end of an official meeting that do not appear on the agenda

examples.text: I think we've finished item four. Now is there any other business?

definitions.definition: to be very good
to have everything that you need in order to be able to start something immediately

examples.text: All we need is a car and we'll be in business.

definitions.definition: to regard a particular activity as an essential part of what you do

examples.text: Restaurant owners everywhere are in the business of building relationships.

definitions.definition: a way of saying that things will continue as normal despite a difficult situation

examples.text: It's business as usual at the factory, even while investigators sift through the bomb wreckage.

definitions.definition: a way of saying that financial and commercial matters are the important things to consider and you should not be influenced by friendship, etc.
to start dealing with the matter that needs to be dealt with, or doing the work that needs to be done

examples.text: Let’s get down to business right away—we’ll stop for coffee later.
OK, let's get down to business.

definitions.definition: to do the things that you normally do

examples.text: streets filled with people going about their daily business
market traders going about their daily business

definitions.definition: to have no right to do something

examples.text: You have no business being here.

definitions.definition: very much, very fast, very well, etc.

examples.text: I've been working like nobody's business to get it finished in time.

definitions.definition: to be serious in your intentions

examples.text: He has the look of a man who means business.
He says he's going to make changes, and I think he means business.

definitions.definition: to think about your own affairs and not ask questions about or try to get involved in other people’s lives

examples.text: ‘What are you reading?’ ‘Mind your own business!’
I was just sitting there, minding my own business, when a man started shouting at me.

definitions.definition: not to be intending to do something (which it would be surprising for you to do)

examples.text: I'm not in the business of getting other people to do my work for me.

definitions.definition: having stopped operating as a business because there is no more money or work available

examples.text: The new regulations will **put** many small businesses **out of business**.

definitions.definition: to look for customers, passengers, etc. in order to do business

examples.text: taxis plying for hire outside the theatre

wordOrigin: Old English bisignis ‘anxiety’ (see busy, -ness); the sense ‘state of being busy’ was used from Middle English down to the 18th cent., but is now differentiated as busyness. The use ‘appointed task’ dates from late Middle English, and from it all the other current senses have developed.
